channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Thai Cabinet Names New Central Bank Chief
item.description: Thailand’s cabinet has named the next central bank governor, picking dovish Vitai Ratanakorn over Deputy Gov. Roong Poshyananda Mallikamas.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: RBA Board Awaits Inflation Update Before Moving to Cut Rates
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia’s monetary policy board kept interest rates on hold earlier this month, deciding that a more gradual pace of cuts was needed.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: The global economy is sailing through this year’s historic increase in tariffs, displaying an unexpected trait: resilience
item.description: Trade, production, growth and other global economic vitals are proving resilient almost four months after President Trump’s “Liberation Day” tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Tom Fairless

item.title: Firms Cautious About Raising Prices, Bank of Canada Survey Says
item.description: Canadian companies face higher costs to purchase goods and services but are limited in raising consumer prices due to competitive pressures and weaker demand, according to quarterly surveys published Monday by the Bank of Canada.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: U.S. Leading Indicators Show Economic Clouds Gathering
item.description: The U.S. economy is set to slow, leading economic indicators say, with the impact of tariffs becoming more pronounced in the second half of the year through higher prices.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Key to Whether Anticipated ECB Hold Is an End Or A Pause
item.description: The central bank is expected to leave borrowing costs unchanged for the first time in a year Thursday. But that might prove to be a brief pause.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told the president privately in recent days that ousting Jerome Powell entailed risks, including possible effects on the economy and potential legal and political obstacles
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told the president that ousting Jerome Powell entailed risks, including possible effects on the economy and potential legal and political obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: If President Trump succeeds in forcing out Fed Chair Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve would no longer be an independent check on inflation, @greg_ip writes
item.description: Without independence, the Fed couldn’t be trusted to give priority to low inflation over the president’s other priorities.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: A bill unveiled Friday aims to provide government backing for second mortgages to finance construction of increasingly popular accessory dwelling units
item.description: A bill unveiled Friday aims to provide government backing for second mortgages to finance construction of increasingly popular accessory dwelling units.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Focus on U.S. PMI, ECB Decision, Japan Elections
item.description: Purchasing managers’ surveys in the U.S. and a number of other countries will be watched closely. A decision by the European Central Bank will be the other highlight of the week.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires Staff

item.title: Home-building recovered a little in the U.S. last month but remains down on the year.
item.description: Home-building recovered a little in the U.S. last month but tariffs continued to cause uncertainty in the sector.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Trump’s threat to attempt to fire the Fed chair has raised a potentially unanswerable question: What would the global economy look like without an independent U.S. central bank?
item.description: It isn’t just the U.S. Other countries have also come to expect an independent U.S. central bank.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Does President Trump have the authority to fire Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell?
item.description: The president may try to terminate the Fed chair’s tenure early. But whether Trump has the ability to do so isn’t clear.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined to 221,000 last week, the Labor Department said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Swiss Exports Slip as Frontrunning Fades, Strong Franc Hits Demand
item.description: Exports decreased 5.3% as tariff frontrunning reversed and a strong franc likely squeezed demand.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Climb in Australian Jobless Rate Opens Door to Rate Cut
item.description: Australia’s unemployment rate rose unexpectedly in June, significantly boosting the case for an interest-rate cut in August.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: EU Exports to U.S. Cool as Trans-Atlantic Trade Faces Tariff Test
item.description: Exports to the U.S. fell for the second consecutive month in May after a first-quarter boom, but remained higher than a year earlier.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump wants tariffs, the higher the better, WSJ’s @greg_ip writes. Whether that is achieved unilaterally or through deals is secondary.
item.description: The president wants tariffs, the higher the better. Whether that is achieved unilaterally or via deals is secondary.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Leading Economies Must Work Together to Fix Imbalances, or Face Instability, Says BOE’s Bailey
item.description: The U.S., China and other leading economies should work together to agree on a set of national policies that will help narrow the large imbalances that now threaten the global trade system, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: EU Trade Chief to Contact U.S. Officials After 30% Tariff Threat
item.description: The European Union’s top trade negotiator said he intends to speak to his U.S. counterparts Monday, adding he senses a good outcome for both sides.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Trump is threatening to ramp up the U.S. trade war with Europe, and costs to move products like cars, pharmaceutical products and airplane parts across the Atlantic are at stake
item.description: A new Trump tariff threat targets a bloc of 27 countries that add up to the largest U.S. trade partner.
item.dc:creator: Inti Pacheco

item.title: U.K. Economy Unexpectedly Slumps to Second Straight Month of Contraction
item.description: The economy contracted in May, a sharp reversal in fortune that makes it more likely the BOE will cut its key interest rate soon.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined last week, the Labor Department said, although the report suggested that the size of the unemployed population continued to grow in June.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Without Remedy, Countries With Aging Populations Are Set for Weaker Income Growth, Says OECD
item.description: Incomes in rich countries are going to grow much more slowly as populations age unless more women, older people and migrants can be persuaded to work, the OECD said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: The number of first-time home buyers is dwindling, and they are handing a win to landlords
item.description: America’s renter population has hit a record because fewer people can afford to get on the housing ladder.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.description: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. job growth looked solid in June, but the headline number hides a stark reality: Many private employers aren’t hiring anymore.
item.description: The U.S. economy added 147,000 jobs in June, but nearly half were in government.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: Food Prices Rose in June, Driven by Meat, Vegetable-Oil Increases
item.description: Food prices rose in June as higher meat, vegetable-oil and dairy prices offset lower cereal and sugar prices, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the U.N. said.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Hoppe

item.title: U.S. job growth appears strong on the surface, but the underlying pace has been slowing
item.description: Even if Thursday’s jobs report comes in strong, a look behind the headline number tells a different story.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Meanwhile, Bank of England Gov. Bailey says that the ‘direction of interest rates continues to be downwards’
item.description: The central bank’s key interest rate is below the level at which it neither stimulates nor restricts growth, while underlying inflation is set to rise slowly, Gov. Kazuo Ueda said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: After the New York City primaries, look to Texas and other red states for lessons on how to make housing markets work, @greg_ip writes
item.description: Austin, Texas, and other red-state cities have set an example for how to make housing markets work.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: The Conference Board’s June consumer-confidence index fell to 93, from 98.4 in May, surprising analysts
item.description: U.S. consumer confidence slipped in June, reversing an improvement in May, according to the Conference Board.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.K. Consumer Sentiment Edges Up Again Despite Global Turbulence
item.description: The uptick was likely fuelled by easing price inflation and a cut to interest rates in May.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Consumers are making spending decisions in the fog of trade war, uncertain about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation of companies’ push for more profits
item.description: Consumers are making spending decisions in a haze of uncertainty about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation or companies’ push for more profits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Pinsker

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos
